writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned against the windowsill of his loft, New York City sprawling beneath him like a chaotic masterpiece. He absentmindedly twirled a paintbrush between his fingers, a habit he picked up from his days of crafting perfect forgeries. The hum of the city was a comforting backdrop as he pondered the offer that had just come his way.

"Come on, Neal," Mozzie had said, his eyes gleaming with a familiar mischief. "One last job. The score of a lifetime."

Neal had smiled, the way he always did when Mozzie got excited, but something inside him twisted uncomfortably. The old thrill, the rush of the heist—it was there, but buried under layers of something new. Responsibility? Morality? He wasn't sure.

Turning away from the window, Neal's gaze fell on the stacks of case files on his desk, reminders of his partnership with Peter Burke and his time working with the FBI. It had been a wild ride, one that had changed him in ways he hadn't fully understood until now. He'd become more than just a charming con artist; he’d become someone who could do real good.

Neal picked up his phone and dialed a number he knew by heart. The line rang twice before a familiar voice answered.

"Burke."

"Hey, Peter. It's me."

"Neal, what's up? Everything okay?"

Neal hesitated. Peter Burke was more than just his handler; he was a friend, a mentor, the voice of reason in a life that had often teetered on the edge of chaos. "Yeah, everything's fine. Just... needed to talk."

Peter's silence spoke volumes. He knew Neal well enough to sense when something was off. "What’s going on, Neal?"

Neal took a deep breath, the words tumbling out before he could stop them. "Mozzie's got a job. A big one. He wants me to help."

There was a pause on the other end of the line. "And you're considering it?"

Neal laughed, a humorless sound. "I don't know. It feels wrong, Peter. Like... I’ve come too far to go back."

Peter's voice was calm, steady. "You have changed, Neal. But the temptation is always going to be there. The question is, what do you want your life to be?"

Neal closed his eyes, the weight of the question settling on his shoulders. What did he want? The thrill of the heist had always been intoxicating, but the satisfaction of solving a case, of doing something good, was a different kind of rush. One that didn’t leave him looking over his shoulder.

"You're right," Neal said quietly. "I don't want to go back."

"Then don't," Peter replied simply. "You have a choice, Neal. And you've already made it."

Neal hung up the phone, feeling a sense of clarity wash over him. He walked back to the window, the city lights twinkling like stars. This was his world now, a world where he could make a difference.

The door to the loft creaked open, and Mozzie stepped inside, his expression a mix of hope and trepidation. "So, what's the verdict? Are we in?"

Neal turned to face his old friend, a sad smile on his lips. "I'm out, Moz. I can't do it."

Mozzie's face fell, but he nodded, understanding in his eyes. "You've really changed, Neal."

"Maybe," Neal said, a hint of his old charm returning. "Or maybe I've just found something better."

Mozzie sighed, a dramatic gesture that was so very him. "Well, if you ever change your mind, you know where to find me."

Neal chuckled. "I do. And Moz? Stay out of trouble."

Mozzie grinned, the mischievous glint back in his eyes. "No promises."

As Mozzie left, Neal felt a sense of peace settle over him. He wasn't just fooling himself. He had changed. And for the first time, he was okay with that.

Neal glanced at the stacks of case files, a small smile playing on his lips. There was work to be done, and he was ready for it. The world was still a chaotic masterpiece, but he had found his place in it. 

And that was worth more than any heist.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley had always prided himself on his impeccable timing. And yet, there he was, standing in the middle of a dusty road in Lebanon, Kansas, staring at Dean Winchester like a man who had seen a ghost. Which, considering their line of work, wasn't entirely implausible. But this wasn’t a ghost. This was very much the living, breathing Dean Winchester, complete with that infuriatingly charming smirk.

“Crowley,” Dean drawled, hands stuffed into the pockets of his leather jacket. “Long time no see.”

Crowley cleared his throat, trying to regain his composure. “Dean. To what do I owe the pleasure?”

Dean shrugged nonchalantly, but his eyes were scanning Crowley with a curiosity that betrayed his casual facade. “Just passing through. Heard some rumors about a demon king making waves. Thought I’d check it out.”

Crowley chuckled, a sound that was more nervous than he cared to admit. “Always on the job, aren’t you, Squirrel?”

Dean’s smirk widened, and for a moment, Crowley was transported back to the countless nights they’d spent in dingy motel rooms, plotting their next move against whatever new threat loomed over them. It was a different time, one where lines were blurred and alliances were as fragile as glass. 

Those nights had been filled with late-night confessions, the kind that only surfaced when the world was quiet and the weight of their burdens pressed down like a vice. Crowley remembered the way Dean’s eyes softened, the way his voice dropped to a whisper when he spoke of his fears, his regrets. It was during one of those nights that Crowley had stolen a kiss, a desperate attempt to bridge the chasm between them.

Dean hadn’t pulled away. Instead, he’d deepened the kiss, as if trying to pour all his unspoken words into that single moment. They’d never talked about it afterward, but it had changed something between them, a shift that neither was willing to acknowledge but couldn’t ignore.

And now, here they were, standing on the precipice of something new and terrifying. Crowley had never been one for sentimentality, but seeing Dean again made him wonder if perhaps some things were worth rewriting the plan for.

“Fancy a drink?” Crowley offered, gesturing toward a nearby bar that looked like it hadn’t seen a renovation since the 70s.

Dean’s eyes twinkled with amusement. “Why not?”

Inside, the bar was dimly lit, the air thick with the scent of stale beer and worn leather. They found a corner booth, and Crowley ordered a bottle of whiskey, pouring them both generous measures. 

“To old times,” Dean said, raising his glass.

“To new beginnings,” Crowley countered, clinking his glass against Dean’s.

The whiskey burned as it went down, a welcome distraction from the whirlwind of thoughts racing through Crowley’s mind. He watched Dean over the rim of his glass, taking in the familiar lines of his face, the way his eyes crinkled at the corners when he laughed. It was like seeing a favorite book after years apart, the words still etched in his memory but the pages worn and well-loved.

“So, what’s the plan, Crowley?” Dean asked, leaning back in his seat. “You always have one.”

Crowley sighed, setting his glass down. “I had a plan. It involved staying far away from hunters and living a quiet life. But then I ran into you.”

Dean’s gaze softened, and for a moment, Crowley saw the vulnerability that lay beneath the hunter’s tough exterior. “And now?”

“Now, I’m not so sure,” Crowley admitted. “But I do know one thing. I missed you, Dean.”

Dean’s breath hitched, his fingers tightening around his glass. “I missed you too, Crowley.”

The words hung between them, heavy and laden with unspoken promises. Crowley reached across the table, his fingers brushing against Dean’s. It was a small gesture, but it spoke volumes.

Dean’s eyes met his, and in that moment, Crowley knew that whatever came next, they would face it together. 

Late-night confessions turned into stolen kisses, and stolen kisses turned into something more. They found themselves tangled in a life that was both familiar and strange, filled with federal agents and family barbecues. It was a life Crowley had never imagined for himself, but one he wouldn’t trade for anything.

Because some things, Crowley realized, were worth rewriting the plan for. And Dean Winchester was at the top of that list.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, eyes twinkling with mischief as the precinct buzzed with the usual morning chaos. Peter Burke, his ever-dutiful handler, was neck-deep in a heated debate with Agent Jones over the legal ramifications of their latest case. Neal couldn't help but smirk—Peter's passion for procedure was both endearing and, at times, exasperating.

"So what you're saying, Jones," Peter said, voice rising with barely contained frustration, "is that we should just ignore due process because it's 'too slow'?"

Jones sighed, rubbing his temples. "I'm just saying, Peter, that sometimes we need to bend the rules a bit to get results. These criminals aren't playing by the book. Why should we?"

Neal's smirk faltered. He'd lived most of his life bending, if not outright breaking, the rules. But the time he'd spent with Peter had taught him something invaluable: the rules existed for a reason. And so, before he could second-guess himself, he found his voice rising above the din.

"Actually, Jones," Neal began, all eyes turning to him in surprise, "Peter's right."

Peter's eyebrows shot up, a mixture of amusement and incredulity playing across his features. "Oh, this should be good," he muttered under his breath.

Neal ignored him, focusing on Jones. "I know it seems like cutting corners is the faster route, but it only makes things messier in the long run. We need airtight cases, evidence collected by the book. Otherwise, we're no better than the criminals we're trying to catch."

Jones blinked, clearly not expecting a lecture on legal ethics from the notorious Neal Caffrey. "But Neal," he protested, "you've—"

"I know," Neal interrupted, raising a hand. "I've done it all. Forged signatures, bypassed security, lied through my teeth. But I've also seen what happens when cases fall apart because of one procedural misstep. It's not worth it."

Peter's lips twitched into a grin. "Well, well, well. Look who's become a stickler for the rules."

Neal shot him a mock glare. "Don't get used to it, Peter. This is a one-time thing."

Peter laughed, clapping Neal on the shoulder. "Oh, I don't think I'll ever let you live this down."

Jones shook his head, a wry smile tugging at his lips. "Alright, alright. I get it. We'll do it by the book."

The room seemed to exhale collectively, the tension easing as they returned to their respective tasks. Peter, however, wasn't done teasing Neal. "You know, there's a tag for this kind of transformation. What do they call it? 'Character development'? Or maybe 'reformed con artist has a moment of clarity'?"

"How about 'Neal Caffrey surprises everyone, including himself'?" Neal shot back, grinning.

Peter chuckled, shaking his head. "Whatever you call it, I'm glad to see it."

Later that evening, as they walked out of the office together, Peter couldn't resist bringing it up again. "So, Neal, what brought on that sudden defense of proper procedure? Did you hit your head this morning?"

Neal rolled his eyes. "Believe it or not, Peter, I do listen when you talk. And sometimes, just sometimes, you make a good point."

Peter stopped, turning to face Neal with a serious expression. "I know I give you a hard time, but I hope you realize how much I appreciate what you bring to the team. You've got a perspective none of us have, and it's invaluable. Even if it means occasionally defending the rules you love to break."

Neal's grin softened into something more genuine. "Thanks, Peter. I appreciate that. And for the record, I don't love breaking the rules. I just... enjoy the challenge."

Peter laughed, clapping him on the back. "Well, let's hope your newfound appreciation for the law sticks around for a while. We could use more moments like today."

As they walked towards the subway, Neal couldn't help but reflect on how much his life had changed since he started working with the FBI. The thrill of the con was still there, but it was different now. There was something deeply satisfying about playing by the rules and still coming out on top. Maybe, just maybe, he was starting to understand why Peter was so passionate about it.

"Hey, Peter," Neal said, a teasing glint in his eye. "Think this means I'm finally going straight?"

Peter snorted. "Let's not get ahead of ourselves, Caffrey. One step at a time."

Neal laughed, the sound echoing through the bustling streets of New York. For the first time in a long while, he felt a sense of peace. Maybe he was still a con artist at heart, but with Peter by his side, he was more than that. He was part of something bigger, something that mattered. And that, he realized, was the greatest con of all.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
The silence on the bridge of the USS Enterprise was unnerving, almost as if the ship itself were holding its breath. Captain James T. Kirk stood at the center, his gaze fixed on the viewscreen, which displayed nothing but the vast, indifferent expanse of space. The ship was stranded, dead in space, and despite their collective ingenuity, the reason for the failure remained maddeningly elusive.

"Scotty," Kirk's voice broke the heavy silence, calm but edged with urgency. "Any progress?"

Montgomery Scott, the chief engineer, rubbed his temples. His usually bright eyes were shadowed with worry. "Nae, Captain. It's as if the ship's spirit has just... gone out." 

A touch of humor flickered in Kirk's eyes, despite the gravity of the situation. "The Enterprise doesn't give up that easily, Scotty. Neither do we."

Spock, standing at his station, interjected with his characteristic cool logic. "Captain, I have run every diagnostic available. There is no logical explanation for this failure."

"Well, maybe it's not logic we're dealing with," Lieutenant Uhura suggested from her communications console. "Maybe it's something... else."

Kirk nodded thoughtfully. "We need to consider every possibility. Scotty, keep at it. We’re counting on you."

In the bowels of the ship, the engine room was a hive of activity. Scotty moved among his team, his mind a whirlwind of theories and counter-theories. He'd seen the Enterprise through countless scrapes, but this... this felt different. More personal. Almost as if the ship were trying to tell them something, but they weren't listening.

"Chief," a young ensign called out, "we've checked every system, every circuit. It's all fine, but nothing's working."

Scotty sighed. "Aye, lad. It's like trying to find a needle in a haystack when ye don't even know if there's a needle."

As the hours ticked by, the situation grew more dire. Life support systems were on backup power, and even that was dwindling. The crew's morale was fraying at the edges, and Kirk's usual optimism was starting to crack.

In the mess hall, McCoy sat with Spock, the two an unlikely pair in their silent contemplation. "Spock," McCoy said, breaking the silence, "do you ever get the feeling we're missing something... important?"

Spock raised an eyebrow. "Doctor, I find that feeling to be particularly unproductive. However, it is possible that we are overlooking a variable."

"Yeah, well," McCoy grumbled, "let's hope Scotty finds it before we're all breathing recycled air."

Back in engineering, Scotty was alone, staring at the warp core. He'd sent his team to rest, knowing they needed their strength if they were to solve this. He ran a hand over the console, almost a caress. "C'mon, lass," he whispered. "Give me a sign."

And then it hit him. It wasn't a sign he needed; it was a signal. He rushed to the nearest console and began a series of frantic calculations, his fingers flying over the controls. "Of course," he muttered. "Of course!"

"Captain," his voice crackled over the intercom, "I need ye in engineering. Now."

Kirk and Spock arrived within moments, their expressions a mix of hope and concern. "What have you got, Scotty?" Kirk asked.

"It's not the ship, sir. It's something external. A dampening field, invisible to our sensors, sapping our power."

Spock's eyes widened slightly. "A dampening field? But who—"

"That's what I aim to find out," Scotty interrupted. "But first, we need to disrupt it. I've got a plan, but it'll take every ounce of power we've got left."

Kirk nodded. "Do it."

The next few minutes were a blur of activity as Scotty and his team rerouted power, bypassed circuits, and prepared for one last desperate push. "Hold on to your hats, lads and lasses," Scotty called out. "Here we go."

With a final keystroke, the ship lurched, shuddered, and then... power surged back through the systems. Lights flickered on, consoles hummed to life, and the familiar thrum of the warp core filled the room.

"We're back," Kirk said, a grin spreading across his face. "Well done, Scotty."

But Scotty wasn't done. He was already scanning the area, determined to find the source of the dampening field. And there it was, a small, cloaked satellite, hidden in the shadow of a nearby asteroid.

"Captain," Scotty said, "I think we found our culprit."

Kirk's smile turned into a determined frown. "Let's pay them a visit."

As the Enterprise moved to intercept, the crew felt a renewed sense of purpose. They had been tested, and they had prevailed. And as always, they would face whatever came next together, as a family.

"Scotty," Kirk said, clapping a hand on the engineer's shoulder, "you never cease to amaze me."

Scotty grinned, the weight of the past hours lifting. "Just doing my job, sir. Just doing my job."

And with that, the Enterprise sailed onward, ready for the next adventure.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
The air in the office was tense, a palpable unease hanging over the usually bustling White Collar division. Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, his fingers drumming a soft, erratic rhythm against the armrest. Across the room, Peter Burke was deep in conversation with the latest thorn in their collective side: Special Agent Dana Simmons.

Neal had heard the whispers. Simmons was relentless, a stickler for protocol and a bloodhound when it came to sniffing out any hint of misconduct. And now, she was here, auditing Peter’s team with a focus so sharp it could cut through steel.

“Caffrey,” Simmons called, her voice slicing through the office noise. Neal sauntered over, a charming smile in place, but his eyes were wary.

“Yes, Agent Simmons?”

She handed him a file, her gaze unreadable. “Care to explain this?”

Neal flipped open the file, his heart skipping a beat as he scanned the contents. It was a detailed report on a recent art forgery case, one that had crossed his radar but hadn’t landed on his to-do list. The forged piece was eerily similar to his own style, down to the last brushstroke.

“I didn’t do this,” Neal said, his voice steady but firm.

“Of course, you didn’t,” Simmons replied, her tone dripping with skepticism. “But the evidence suggests otherwise. I’d like to know why.”

Peter, having finished his conversation, approached them. “Is there a problem, Agent Simmons?”

“Just following up on some inconsistencies, Agent Burke,” she replied, her expression neutral. “I’ll need to interview your consultant further.”

Neal met Peter’s eyes, a silent communication passing between them. Peter’s nod was almost imperceptible, a signal of trust. Neal had an idea, but it was risky—bordering on reckless. Still, it was the only way to clear his name and protect Peter’s team.

“Agent Simmons,” Neal began, “if I could have a day to look into this, I’m confident I can provide you with the real culprit.”

She arched an eyebrow. “You have twenty-four hours, Caffrey. Don’t disappoint me.”

---

Neal spent the night combing through his old contacts, utilizing the network that had once made him the most wanted art forger. He knew he was walking a fine line, but he needed to get to the bottom of this. It wasn’t just his freedom on the line—Peter’s reputation and the integrity of the entire team were at stake.

The breakthrough came at dawn. An old associate, a master forger known as Alistair, had resurfaced, boasting about a recent commission that matched the forgery in question. Neal’s mind worked quickly, formulating a plan that was both clever and borderline insane.

By the time Neal arrived at the office, he had everything he needed. Peter was waiting, tension etched into his features. “What’s the plan?”

“Trust me, Peter,” Neal said, flashing a confident smile that didn’t quite reach his eyes. “I just need you to play along.”

---

Simmons was back, her eyes narrowing as Neal approached with Peter in tow. “Well, Caffrey? Time’s up.”

Neal handed her a new file, his demeanor calm and collected. “Alistair Finch,” he said, watching her reaction. “He’s the one who forged the painting. I’ve included proof of his involvement.”

Simmons scanned the file, her expression hardening. “And how exactly did you come by this information?”

Neal shrugged, a casual gesture that belied the tension in his muscles. “Let’s just say I have my sources.”

Simmons looked from Neal to Peter and back again. “This better hold up, Caffrey. If I find out you’re involved in any way—”

“I’m clean,” Neal interrupted, his voice firm. “You have my word.”

She studied him for a moment longer before nodding curtly. “I’ll verify this. For now, consider yourself on probation.”

As she walked away, Peter let out a breath he didn’t know he’d been holding. “Neal, that was—”

“Reckless? Yeah, I know,” Neal admitted, a grin tugging at his lips. “But it worked, didn’t it?”

Peter shook his head, a mix of exasperation and admiration in his eyes. “You’re going to be the death of me, Caffrey.”

“Not if I can help it,” Neal replied, his grin widening.

As the office returned to its usual hum, Neal felt a sense of relief wash over him. The line between clever and reckless had blurred, but in the end, he’d managed to protect what mattered most—the trust and bond between him and Peter. And in the world of White Collar, that was worth more than any forged masterpiece.
